captions.text:
Queen Lion of the animal kingdom is looking
to improve her democracy. She recently allowed

citizens to elect representatives to the Jungle
Council which governs the kingdom.

However, she recognizes that her citizens
are not happy with the voting system. Let’s

watch an election on one of the small islands
of her Kingdom to see why:

On this island there are three political parties:
the two big ones: Kea and Tuatara, and a small
third party, Kakapo.

On election day, the citizens each cast one
vote for a local candidate they want to represent

the range they live in. The results are as
follows:

With the average across the island that Tuatara
gets 49%, Kea gets 48% and Kakapo gets 3%.

The election is run using First Past the Post,
meaning that candidate with the most votes

wins. Because Tuatara got the most votes in
each range, they get to control 100% of the
seats on the council.

And this is why so many citizens are unhappy.
The majority of them, the 51% who voted for

other parties, get no representation on the
council at all.

This seems unfair to Queen Lion but she’s
not sure how to fix it. The citizens like

having local representatives and don’t want
to change the range boundaries.

But luckily Kiwi, one of the citizens of this
island, has a suggestion for Queen Lion on

how she can make the system better while keeping
local representation and leaving the ranges
as they are.

The idea is called Mixed Member Proportional
or MMP and it makes two changes: the number

of seats on the council is doubled and each
citizen gets two votes, not one.
Here’s how it works:

At first, election day for Kiwi is just the
same as before.

He gets a list of candidates running to represent
his local range on the council. Kiwi picks

one and the winner will be the candidate with
the most votes.

So far the system is no better – Tuatara
again wins all the local elections and still

more than half of the citizens don’t have
any representation. But here’s how Kiwi’s

second vote – and those extra seats on the
council – fix this.

Kiwi uses his second vote to pick his favorite
political party.

These second votes are tallied up and show
the percentage of support that each of the

political parties has among the citizens as
a whole and reveals how imbalanced the council
is so far.

To fix this imbalance, members of the political
parties are added, one at a time, to make
the council more proportional.

Tuatara is the most over-represented and Kea
the most underrepresented, so Kea gets the
first empty seat.

This continues, adding one Kea at a time until
both Turatara and Kea are over-represented

and Kakapo is under-represented, so they get
the final seat.

Now, the jungle council represents, as close
as possible, the actual preferences of the

citizens – which is a huge improvement over
the old, first past the post method.

There is, however, one interesting question
that should arise at this point:

Exactly who decides which members of the parties
get those extra seats?

The way it works is that, before the election,
the political parties make a list of their

favorite candidates in the order that they
want them to get on the council.

So, if there is only get one extra seat, the
name at the top of their list is chosen. If

they get two seats, the first two are chosen,
and so on.

This makes MMP a bit different from other
voting methods in that it makes political

parties an official part of the way the election
works.

This may give the party leaders greater control
over their members because they can reward

or punish their actions by changing their
placement on the party list.

While this may be a disadvantage of MMP there
are a number of other benefits that Queen
Lion, in particular, likes.

Because fewer votes are wasted, it mostly
Eliminates Gerrymandering and prevents minority
rule.

It also gives more choice to the citizens
by encouraging political diversity.
This point is worth expanding on.

Notice how, with MMP, the percentage of votes
for the local representatives isn’t the

same as for the parties. This is because in
the local elections, citizens have to vote
strategically.

For example, Kakapo voters don’t like Tuatara
at all, but they can tolerate Kea. Since there

are so few Kakapo voters they know that their
candidate doesn’t have a chance of winning

the local election, so it’s really a race
between the two big parties. Thus many of

the Kakapo will vote Kea in the hope that
he might win and be their representative.

However, when it comes to voting for their
favorite political party, this strategy doesn’t

matter. The more votes a party gets the more
representatives it has on the council.

So citizens are free to vote for smaller parties
they like like knowing that every vote counts.

Queen Lion reviews her options and decides
to switch her Kingdom to MMP. Now, for the

first time, the Jungle Council is a true reflection
of what her citizens want.

This is not a desirable system.

50% direct seats the actual 20% they represent).´

with bad list ranks have incentive to blow up the parliament. MPs who did 
great and whose party actually won more votes can still lose their seats 
because the parliament shrunk.﻿

comments.text:
I HOPE THIS HELPS SOMEBODY ! ....

Germany is a paradim to show, why MMP is horrible, too. :( Because there 
are so many more aspects, which matter. I can only name a few examples here:

There are 2 big parties and 3-4 smaller parties currently in the federal 
and state parliaments in Germany. That seems to be good and more 
representative. Here is the reality: The big parties (CDU - conservatives 
and SPD - liberals on paper, not really) block one smaller party completely 
called the "the leftists". So Leftists have never any chance to have any 
power in any important decision. They get just ignored. The big parties 
prefer to pick each a junior partner close to their political agenda for a 
government coalition. In the past it was either CDU + FPD (some sort of 
soft Liberterians) or lesser times SPD + Greens. The junior partner gets 
always screwed horribly by his big partner, has to compromise a lot and has 
to abandon his principles. So last election FPD didnt make it in the 
parliament, because everybody saw, they have no own program, they just want 
to be the junior partner of the CDU to get the money for gov. jobs. However 
CDU hates Greenies, so they formed a so called "Great coalition" with the 
SPD.

This is a nightmare on many levels.  They have together 80 % of all seats 
in the German parliament. They can change the constitution, whenever they 
wanted (75 % needed). The opposition has only less than 20 % (Green and 
leftists) can not even do all opposition work, i.e. if they wanted to start 
a parliamentary commission to investigate something, they needed 25 %.

Another nightmare is the list. A candidate can lose in his constituency 
horribly bad. If he is on top of the list, it does not matter and he comes 
in the parliament anyways via the list. Even Greens, who fuck up, go to 
parliament via the list, if their party gets over the 5 % barrier. This 
makes it impossible to punish certain politicians. For example Frank Walter 
Steinmeier (SPD) lost as Chancellor candidate vs Angela Merkel (CDU) with a 
record low for his party of 23 % in 2009. He still came in the parliament 
via the list. Now in the great coalition he is in the government again and 
minister of foreign affairs. Some polls say, he might have a chance as 
chancellor candidate against Angela Merkel, because there is no better 
candidate in the SPD. WAIT WHAT? Yea, really. There is another guy, 
Wolfgang Schäuble, minister of finance. He is since almost 50 (!) years in 
the parliament and most Germans, most of the world, hate him. But he is in 
the CDU and they always win or make it in the parliament. He is always on 
top of that list. Many politicians in SPD and CDU are professional 
politicians, who lost votes, but it did not matter, the list saved them.

There was a couple years ago a poll: 70 % hated the goverment of the CDU. 
But at the same time, the same 70 % said they like Angela Merkel (CDU), the 
chancellor of that same goverment. At this point - it is over. Propaganda 
won.

In the last years, some new parties were founded, AfD and Pirates in 
particular. But the CDU has appr. 100,000 party members everywhere in the 
executive, judicative and legislative and they controll the media. The SPD 
is simular. They have many times more money than these newcomers, are state 
financed and they get the most private donations by corporations. So the 
newcomers just get trashed by media and PR campaignes. The pirates are 
done, never had a chance. They cant do anything about it - unless they get 
backed by big private doners like AfD. Americans know, where this leads to 
then. It is not as bad as in the USA, but in Germany almost EVERY 
politicians is corrupt. The next problem is called "coalition discipline". 
If a member of say the CDU in the parliament does not do, what the bosses 
want (Bosses are i.e. Angela Merkel or Schäuble) - he will get no more 
money from the CDU for his next election campaigne, infact he will be 
deleted from the list. End of his carrier in the party and end of his 
political carrier in almost 100% of all cases. This violates the 
constitution, because a member of parliament should decide by his own will 
and conscience on what bill he wants to vote for and which not. The bosses 
of these parties dont care. They also violate the constitution by illegal 
use of donations or they use their stuff for election campaignes etc.

Gerrymandering still happens in Germany, too. It has nothing to do with the 
voting system. The CDU did it. The SPD also. Fortunately not as bad as in 
USA. It is basically a 2 party system - for 70 years the same 2, since the 
beginnig of the FRG after WWII - with some small dots around, who are too 
weak to matter in any big way. And it will stay this 2 party system, 
because these 2 are too powerful - unless some catastrophy like a financial 
collapse from abroad washs them way. But even then. If they lost both in 
one election on the federal level. They still can block everything for 
years in the federal assembly with their state governments.

So this system is designed to remain this way with these 2 parties on top 
forever until it falls.

ps: I know, there is no real democracy in the world. Because there is one 
more problem: if the constituency is too big, it becomes impossible to 
represent all interests. For example Germany is since more than 10 years 
with soldiers in Afghanistan. 70 % of the voters do not want them there, 
but on election day, they can not punish this, because they think, they 
have to vote for which party is best for their wallets. Sad but reality. 
The politicians know this and abuse it. Also democracy in Ancient Greece 
was a completely different society system than in most democracies today. 
Swiss and Island are maybe closest to the democratic ideal - one of the 
reasons is, because they are small countries and politicians did not lose 
touch to their constituency as it happens in imperial "democracies" like 
the USA or EU.﻿

comments.text:
The issue of party bosses using list rankings to favor candidates is daily 
dealt with. In New Zealand (which uses MMP) the Green Party composes it's 
just ranking via the ranked (preferential) votes of party members. Once the 
post knows how it's members voted, the final list is adjusted for gender 
balance and regional balance. But overall, the rankings are openly 
democratic within the party. Why not require all parties to do this? It 
definitely addresses the issue of internal patronage. ﻿
comments.author: linuxluver

comments.text:
+Arioch IV I see that another way. Under PR, my vote helps elect several 
MPs, not just one. If there is one person there in the list I'm not happy 
about, I can vote for some other party..... And have a reasonable 
expectation I will elect people from that other party. But what I'd that 
other party also has someone on their list that I don't like? Well... Maybe 
I need to step back and see the bigger picture. This focus on individual 
candidates is, itself, a product of seeing the world through the FPP lens. 
In a PR world, you may elect 5, 10 or more MPs with your post vote. They 
will all be working to support the values and policies you support... In 
their own way. You're winning. If one of them is a dud they can't do much 
harm and won't be on the list next time anyway. 

If been voting in PR elections in New Zealand since 1996. One of the things 
that happens is you shed the habits of thought that FPP engenders. Placing 
a single candidate you don't like over all the other you do like is just 
one of those habits. Besides, "carpetbagger" is a term that defines FPP, 
where voters get even less choice.
comments.author: linuxluver

comments.text:
+linuxluver The candidates in nearly all systems are chosen by the party, 
but in this system the party chooses who is actually put into office; the 
voters have no say, as they can only vote broadly for the party and not 
individual people. Which means that, in theory, the party can put someone 
in office who the voters would never have accepted in a more direct system. 
Obviously, a party that does this regularly will lose support in the long 
term, but in the short term, a new party that somehow got support could 
pull some very strange shenanigans.

candidates. Under First Past the Post all Conservative / L:iberal / NDP / 
Green / whatever party candidates are chosen by their party. Voters just 
have a lot less real, electable, choice with FPP. With a PR system many 
more candidates are  'in play' for being electable. But in any case, - FPP 
or PR - all the party candidates are chosen by a party. Confusing candidate 
selection with election is erroneous.

This actually isn't a problem with MMP systems, but rather with the very 
structure of the African countries (as well as most post-colonial 
countries) themselves. 'Organically-grown' nations are usually based around 
ethnicities or groupings of similar ethnicities, but post-colonial national 
boundaries were dictated by the colonial power without regard to the actual 
ethnicities on the ground.

With colonised Asian countries this ended up not being a problem for the 
most part entirely due to circumstance, since a single colonial power ended 
up colonising a single ethnicity group (the British in India, the French in 
Southeast Asia, and the Dutch in Indonesia), but since ethnicities were 
more diffuse and much more numerous in Africa and the Middle East, the 
administrative lines ended up causing a lot more problems.

Of Course, New Zealand is really a Westminster form of Parliamentary system 
where there is a culture of having stable governments. Westminster form is 
really a majoritarian form of Parliamentary system. And, I've been there. 
But, other countries that uses MMP or other similar PR systems, they tend 
to have unstable governments. Normally, proportional systems tend to lead 
to a more diverse political structure that may lead it to be a 
centrifugalist one but NZ remains centripetalistic. Countries with a 
Consensus/Contemporal-type of Parliamentary systems with MMP or other PR 
systems are really in trouble of having unstable governments unless the 
electorate are centripetalistic.

comments.text:
+Charles Judiel Baynas Well, having lived with MMP for 7 elections (my 
entire adult life) I can say that it is surprisingly stable. In our country 
we have two major parties who get the majority of the vote and minor 
parties in support. 

Our governments have been stable, we've had one coalition breakdown and 
that was the very first term of MMP (and the party that caused it got 
punished by voters, so it's unlikely to happen again).

However, because they have to make deals and compromise, they can't just 
ram through whatever law changes they want. It's good,it means more debate 
on laws and more reasonable policies.

Considering under FPP we had a party ram through laws despite barely 
getting 40% of the vote, they got a majority of seats. 

And that's not a theoretical discussion, that's a historic reflection of 20 
years of MMP in New Zealand.

You may be interested to know that almost 90% of all democracies use some 
form of proportional representation. MMP is one form of PR. There are many. 
Most of them have no local reps at all. I prefer these as I have had to 
suffer for years a local rep I didn't vote for and who has NO interest in 
my views... So I go to a list MP from the party I support who has been 
chosen to service / represent supporters of my party in the area I live in. 
MMP usually results in an area having several MPs from a variety of parties 
who work to represent an area... Because their party wants to win more 
votes. MMP is FAR better than First Past the Post. I have lived under both. 
MMP for the win!!!!
